0.19.text:
Hello and welcome to the first Truthloader
video of the week. So full of hope, giddy

5.06.text:
with dreams of what might come. And hungover.
So hungover.

10.05.text:
And on this week's Monday show Dad's undercover
army as Britain is forced to dust off all

14.34.text:
it's long retired spies to combat Russia,
A computer has finally beaten THE difinitve

19.88.text:
test of artificial intelligence... By cheating.
And the CIA is on Twitter!

25.34.text:
But first and to Britain's MI6. And they have
a problem. Back in the day it was all about

31.59.text:
the reds under the bed. We in the freedom
loving, democratic, squeeky clean, morally

36.67.text:
infallible West had nothing to fear from our
allies and friends in the Taliban, or Iran,

43.22.text:
or our colonies in Africa. No, all we had
to fear was Russian speaking communists. So

48.97.text:
all our spies spoke Russian. And knew what
was going on in Russia.

54.54.text:
But that's all changed. Post 9/11 British
intelligence is full of young, Google glass

59.21.text:
wearing hipsters who speak Arabic and ride
scooters and fly drones into weddings. Basically,

65.10.text:
the old enemy, Russia, has been forgotten.
And that's a problem, because Russia looks

70.22.text:
like it might be about to become a bit of
an enemy again. And because Britain doesn't

74.85.text:
have any spies who are experts in Russian
affairs any more, it's had to dust off the

80.44.text:
According to documents seen by the Telegraph
newspaper - and those documents were, from

84.57.text:
the sound of it, a bad hollywood script - intelligence
chiefs have been reduced to trawling for veterans,

90.28.text:
most of whom were retired in budget cuts over
a decade ago and are now in their 60s and

96.39.text:
70s, to try and re-hire them for one last
ultra dangerous mission deep behind enemy

100.32.text:
lines. Calling on them to dust off their Judo
skills, infiltrate the Kremlin and take out

105.51.text:
Vladimir Putin's ninja assassins, thus saving
the western world from a crazed lunatic of

110.31.text:
it's own creation. That last bit isn't true,
they'll probably just be sat in a comfy chair

115.75.text:
phone tapping embassies and complaining about
the good old days.

120.02.text:
But what is true is the massive shortfall
in British intelligence specialists - we are

124.50.text:
short by over 700 spies. And even if Britain
manages to fill the blanks with OAP agents

130.06.text:
they've still been out of the loop for ten
years, and what's going on in ukraine is a

134.73.text:
very modern kind of war - a war being fought
on YouTube and LiveLeak and Russia Today and

140.26.text:
Vice as much as it is in the streets of Slavyansk.
So for Britain's ragtag legion of ear hair

146.61.text:
growing, free bus pass collecting pensioner
spies it might well already be too late.

152.57.text:
Next up and to a computer near you and the
announcement, with some fanfare, that the

157.31.text:
Turing test has been smashed. To mark the
60th anniversary of the death of Alan Turing,

162.88.text:
godfather of modern computing, the university
of Reading in the UK organised a test of five

168.10.text:
artificial intelligence supercomputers. Their
aim? To have a spontaneous text conversation

174.02.text:
with a panel of judges, and to convince more
than 30% of them that the computer was a human

179.52.text:
- The so-called Turing test - a test of whether
true AI has been reached. It is THE difinitive

188.16.text:
And for the first time since Alan Turing created
the test back in the 1950s, it's been passed

193.54.text:
in a spontaneous conversation. The winner?
A Russian team using Eugene Goostman, a system

199.87.text:
initially developed in Saint Petersburg way
back in 2001. It's a remarkable milestone,

206.07.text:
which could mark a new era in computing. But
it's not quite what it seems. Because Eugene

211.62.text:
Goostman isn't a simulation of a normal, adult
human. No, he's a 13 year old Ukranian boy

219.18.text:
trying to speak English. Which means that
by using human psychology, the team might

225.40.text:
have sort of bent the rules. See, tell a panel
of human judges that they are dealing with

230.64.text:
a teenager who speaks English as a second
language, and they'll overlook a whole host

235.18.text:
of mistranslations, grammatical errors and
slightly iffy syntax. Instead of thinking,

240.67.text:
"This looks an awful lot like a computer trying
to be human", they'll think, "Aaaw, bless

246.06.text:
him, little Eugene is trying very hard with
his English".

249.24.text:
But whilst it might have been underhand, it
isn't really cheating, because a huge part

253.70.text:
of conversing with humans is psychology and
establishing who you are and your conversational

258.94.text:
limits. In fact, the team behind Eugene more
or less admitted it, saying that "Our main

263.29.text:
idea was that he can claim that he knows anything,
but his age also makes it perfectly reasonable

269.20.text:
that he doesn't know everything. We spent
a lot of time developing a character with

275.84.text:
What does it all mean for us? Well as well
as ushering in a new generation of computer

279.78.text:
simulations, medical and theraputic tools
and the like, it's also a huge threat to web

285.35.text:
security. Phishing viruses that can seem like
a real person to steal your data, hacking

290.53.text:
algorithms that can think as well as number
crunch... Skynet. It's very exciting, but

298.36.text:
And speaking of exciting but a little bit
scary it's time for your comments. And in

302.21.text:
Laura's piece on the peacekeepers being implicated
in torture, murder and kidnappings in CAR,

307.45.text:
Erm, you wrote: How can we be so cruel to
each other? Stuff like this makes me ashamed

317.51.text:
And in Grace's piece on Obamacare NoName NoFame
wrote: "Since when did you turn into Propagandaloader"???

323.85.text:
Oooh that's footage of us getting BURNED.
Damn socialist shills that we are. Fortunately

330.60.text:
once we're rescued from that burning fireball
and taken to hospital, and our wounds dressed,

334.87.text:
and we're taught to walk again, we won't have
to pay for it. Yay free healthcare! But seriously

340.97.text:
on insurance based healthcare if I can buy
a car and drive it to hospital for less than

344.15.text:
than the cost of an ambulance ride to hospital,
that's the sign of a broken system. Just a

351.11.text:
And finally we've had military intelligence,
artificial intelligence and dubious intelligence

355.84.text:
so now it's time for Central Intelligence.
Yes, the CIA is on Twitter. Hooray! The world's

363.34.text:
favourite freedom distributors slash extra
judicial renditioners have hit the microblogging

368.52.text:
site with a whopping three tweets since launching
on Friday. And this was their first tweet.

375.34.text:
No, geniunely, the CIA has a sense of humour.
Though we're not sure why they felt the need

380.78.text:
to hashtag unclassified. Anyway, these three
tweets have got the agency over half a million

386.52.text:
followers in a matter of days, almost all
of whom will be trying to guess their password.

392.20.text:
I reckon it's CIA, with a 1 for an I. Or maybe
911ins1dej0b.

399.82.text:
Anyway, post your thoughts in the comments
and whilst we aren't encouraging you to try

406.49.text:
in any way shape or form (we're really not)
if anyone does manage to hack their account,

411.61.text: it'll deffo make next week's monday show.

414.77.text: That's it for this week. Ciao!
